questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents with painless growths in her axilla and the inguinal folds that have developed over the past 6 months. She has no noteworthy medical history; her BMI is 32 kg/m2. Examination shows multiple soft, flesh-colored, brownish papules with short stalks, some of which are purplish from friction (see image).
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum is the manifestation of a viral infection causing small, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication. The lesions described are soft and pedunculated, contrasting with the firm, dome-shaped appearance of molluscum. The distribution and friction-induced color changes also do not align with typical molluscum presentations.

B) INCORRECT:

Neurofibromas are benign nerve sheath tumors presenting as firm, rubbery nodules. The described lesions are soft, pedunculated papules, differentiating them from neurofibromas.

C) INCORRECT:

Seborrheic keratoses are benign epidermal proliferations that manifest as waxy, well-circumscribed plaques with a 'stuck-on' appearance. They typically occur in older patients and in sun-exposed areas like the face, trunk, or scalp. The soft, pedunculated papules in intertriginous regions described here differ from the usual presentation of seborrheic keratoses.

D) CORRECT:

Acrochordons, or skin tags, are benign, pedunculated lesions that commonly manifest in locations prone to friction such as the lower neck, axilla, inframammary fold, and inguinal regions. They appear as soft, flesh-colored to brownish papules on a narrow stalk, reflecting their composition of loose fibrovascular tissue. These lesions are prevalent in middle-aged, overweight individuals, correlating with increased mechanical stress and potential metabolic associations.

Key learning point: Skin tags, or acrochordons, are benign skin growths that appear as soft, skin-colored or brown papules with short, narrow stalks, commonly found in areas of friction and can become purpuric when traumatized.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-month history of a painless, nonpruritic skin lesion on her right thigh. She initially thought it was an insect bite, but it has slowly increased in size over the past few weeks. Her temperature is 36.7°C, pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. On examination, there is a 0.8-cm hyperpigmented papule. When the lesion is squeezed, the surface retracts inward. A photograph of the lesion is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Common warts (verruca vulgaris) are skin-colored, rough, scaly papules or plaques with a hyperkeratotic surface. They are most commonly located on the hands, feet, and/or knees and dimpling would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Seborrheic keratosis appears as multiple, sharply demarcated, darkly pigmented papules or plaques that have a greasy, wax-like, and stuck-on appearance. They are most common in older adults and are primarily located on the trunk, hands, forearms, and face. Dimpling would not be expected.

C) CORRECT:

Dermatofibroma is a benign skin condition characterized by fibroblast proliferation, which leads to the development of small (3–10 mm in diameter), skin-colored, or brown fibrous nodules, most commonly on the lower extremities. Patients are typically asymptomatic and require no treatment. Surgical excision may be considered for cosmetic reasons, symptomatic lesions, or suspicion of malignancy.

Key learning point: Dermatofibroma is a benign, firm, hyperpigmented nodule that often shows a central dimple when pinched and most commonly occurs on the lower extremities.

D) INCORRECT:

Actinic keratosis is a precancerous skin lesion that typically occurs in individuals with light skin over the age of 50 years. The lesion is initially small with a rough, sandpaper-like surface, that grows slowly in size and becomes erythematous and scaly. The rapid appearance of this patient's skin lesion and the dimple sign are suggestive of another etiology.

E) INCORRECT:

A dysplastic nevus is an atypical mole that is assessed based on the ABCDE criteria. It is typically an evolving lesion with an asymmetric shape, irregular borders, inconsistent color, and diameter that is usually > 6 mm in size. The short history of and dimpling sign in this patient's skin lesion is suggestive of another etiology.
questions.hint: This benign skin lesion that exhibits a positive dimple sign (squeezing leads to an inward retraction of the surface) can occur after insect bites or trauma, but can also develop spontaneously.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of a painless skin lesion on his neck. He reports that the lesion has gradually become darker and is sometimes itchy. He has also noticed a similar lesion on his lower back. He is a retired gardener and has a 40-year history of smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily. His temperature is 36.7°C, pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 123/78 mm Hg. On examination, there is a 0.8-cm hyperpigmented papule on his neck and a 0.6-cm hyperpigmented papule on his lower back, both with a greasy and wax-like appearance. A photograph of the neck lesion is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lentigo maligna (LM) is a precancerous skin lesion caused by long-term exposure to sunlight. While this patient's risk of developing malignant skin lesions is increased, LM manifests as an irregularly shaped, dark macule, unlike the sharply demarcated nodules seen in this patient. Since one of this patient's lesions is on skin that is not sun-exposed (lower back), this diagnosis is very unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

A compound nevus is a benign skin lesion similar in appearance to common moles but usually lighter in color. The fact that it consists of a central raised area surrounded by a flat patch of pigmented skin makes it similar to this patient's lesion, but the dark pigmentation and waxy appearance, in this case, are more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's lesions are consistent with seborrheic keratosis (SK), which often appears as multiple darkly pigmented, clearly demarcated papules or plaques that have a greasy, wax-like appearance. SKs typically develop on exposed body parts such as the hands, arms, trunk, head, and neck, and therefore are more prone to irritation, bleeding, and/or pruritus. Although these lesions are generally benign, the sudden development of multiple SKs may indicate an underlying malignancy (referred to as the Leser-Trélat sign).

Key learning point: Seborrheic keratosis presents as well-demarcated, greasy, wax-like, hyperpigmented papules or plaques, most commonly on the trunk, head, neck, or extremities, and is a benign skin lesion.
Image Description:

Trunk of a patient

Multiple, slightly raised plaques, with varying degrees of pigmentation are visible.

D) INCORRECT:

Actinic keratosis is a UV-induced precancerous skin lesion that initially presents with a sandpaper-like texture and progresses to erythematous, scaly lesions. While this patient's work as a gardener places him at increased risk of developing actinic keratosis, the lesions' greasy, wax-like appearance and the location of one on a body part that is not typically sun-exposed (lower back) make this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

A dysplastic nevus is a benign skin lesion that can occur in all age groups and is often seen in individuals with a genetic disposition (e.g., light skin, multiple common moles). The lesion may be flat or raised and is characterized by an asymmetric shape, irregular borders, and inconsistencies in color. The wax-like, greasy appearance of this patient's lesions is not consistent with dysplastic nevi.
questions.hint: The photograph shows the most common benign skin tumor in older patients.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to your clinic for follow-up. He feels well but is concerned about lesions on his neck that his wife noticed. He is 165 cm tall and weighs 84 kg; BMI is 31. On examination, there are lesions scattered across his neck and axilla. A photograph of the lesions is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Skin tags (acrochordons) are benign outgrowths of normal skin that appear as pedunculated appendices with narrow stalks. The prevalence is 50–60% in individuals aged over 50 years and increases with age. The etiology of skin tags is not fully understood, but they tend to affect areas of the body that experience friction, such as the lower neck, axilla, inframammary fold, and inguinal region. Skin tags are also associated with diabetes and obesity and may be a sign of insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome. Because skin tags are benign lesions, intervention is typically not necessary, but they may be removed for cosmetic purposes using fine-grade scissors, cryosurgery, or electrodesiccation.

Key learning point: Skin tags (acrochordons) are benign, pedunculated skin outgrowths commonly found in areas of friction and are associated with obesity, diabetes, and insulin resistance.

B) INCORRECT:

Dermatofibromas are benign asymptomatic skin lesions that manifest as slow-growing nodules on the skin. In contrast to this patient's lesions, dermatofibromas tend to appear on the lower extremities, are not pedunculated, and do not have a stalk. In addition, dermatofibromas are more common in women, occur at any age, and manifest with a characteristic dimple sign.

C) INCORRECT:

Benign acanthosis nigricans manifests as velvety, hyperpigmented plaques on the skin. Acanthosis nigricans occurs in intertriginous zones (e.g., neck, axial, and/or inframammary fold) and is associated with obesity and diabetes. However, these lesions are associated with symmetrical thickening of the skin and, in some cases, pruritus. Furthermore, they are not pedunculated and do not have a stalk.

D) INCORRECT:

Warts are benign skin lesions resulting from hyperkeratosis and hyperplasia of the epidermis that is typically due to human papillomavirus. In contrast to this patient's lesions, warts manifest as skin-colored, scaly papules/plaques that have a cauliflower-like appearance; they are not pedunculated and do not have a stalk. Common warts occur on the elbows, knees, fingers, and palm while flat warts occur on the face, dorsal hands, and legs, plantar warts on the soles of feet, and anogenital warts on the anus and/or genitals.

E) INCORRECT:

Seborrheic keratosis is a benign outgrowth of keratinocytes and is the most common benign skin tumor in older adults. Lesions can appear on the neck (as with this patient) as well as the trunk, dorsum of the hands, forearms, head, and/or face. However, seborrheic keratosis characteristically manifests as greasy, wax-like papules/plaques that have a “stuck-on” appearance and may become pruritic or bleed easily; they are not pedunculated lesions with a narrow stalk.
questions.hint: The multiple pedunculate appendices with narrow stalks are benign outgrowths of normal skin.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to your clinic because his wife is concerned about lesions on his face that she first noticed 4 months ago. He reports feeling well and says the lesions do not cause him any discomfort. He has a 10-year history of hypertension. His family history is unremarkable. His current medications are hydrochlorothiazide and enalapril. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are two soft, painless, 5-mm papules on the right cheek; a photograph of the lesions is provided. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryotherapy is the most common treatment for seborrheic keratosis. However, cryotherapy is indicated in symptomatic lesions or if the patient requests treatment for cosmetic reasons, which is not the case here.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical salicylic acid is the first-line treatment for warts, which can manifest as soft papules on the face (i.e., flat warts or verruca plana). However, flat warts are more common in younger individuals and they are usually flesh-colored, smooth, and flat, whereas this elderly patient's lesion is darkly pigmented and has a “stuck-on” appearance. Salicylic acid treatment is not recommended for seborrheic keratosis.

C) INCORRECT:

A shave biopsy might be indicated to rule out malignancy in patients with pigmented skin lesions with atypical features (e.g., size > 6 mm; a recent change in shape, size, or color; irregular borders; asymmetry). This patient, however, has a small (5 mm), asymptomatic lesion that has not changed much over the past 4 months and has a waxy, “stuck-on” appearance, all of which are characteristic of seborrheic keratosis.

D) INCORRECT:

An excisional biopsy is indicated for pigmented lesions if there is suspicion for melanoma. According to the ABCDE rule for melanoma, a biopsy should be considered if the lesion is > 6 mm in diameter, asymmetric, has color variegation, irregular borders, or recent change in size, shape, or color. This patient's lesion has a waxy, “stuck-on” appearance characteristic of seborrheic keratosis, for which biopsy is not routinely indicated.

E) CORRECT:

Seborrheic keratosis is a benign, slow-growing lesion that is commonly seen in older individuals. For asymptomatic lesions, such as the one seen here, treatment is generally not necessary and reassurance with follow-up is sufficient. If atypical features are present (e.g., asymmetry, rapid change or growth, ulceration) or if the diagnosis is unclear, a biopsy may be indicated. Treatment with cryotherapy, laser therapy, or surgical excision is appropriate for cosmetic removal or if the lesion becomes symptomatic (e.g., pruritic, painful, or bleeds easily).

In patients with the sudden appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses, known as the Leser-Trélat sign, further investigation is necessary because of this feature's association with malignancies such as lung cancer and gastrointestinal cancer.

Key learning point: Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin lesion in older adults that requires no treatment unless symptomatic or for cosmetic reasons; reassurance and routine follow-up are appropriate.
questions.hint: The photograph shows two sharply demarcated and darkly pigmented papules that have a “stuck-on” appearance. This type of lesion in an older individual is characteristic of seborrheic keratosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of multiple red spots on his trunk. He first noticed these lesions several months ago, and some have increased in size. One day ago, he scratched one of the spots, which bled for several minutes. A photograph of the lesions is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Strawberry angiomas are benign, vascular proliferations that may bleed with trauma, like the lesions seen in this patient. However, strawberry angiomas usually develop in the first weeks of life on the head or neck and then involute by 5–8 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyogenic granulomas are benign, vascular proliferations that bleed with trauma, like the lesions seen in this patient. However, this condition typically manifests as a solitary papule at sites of trauma (particularly on the face, hands, or mucous membranes), unlike the multiple lesions seen here. Moreover, pyogenic granulomas are more prevalent among children, young adults, and pregnant women.

C) INCORRECT:

Seborrheic keratoses are common, benign skin proliferations with a characteristic greasy, stuck-on appearance. Like this patient's papules, seborrheic keratoses typically develop as multiple lesions on the trunk of adult patients. However, they also commonly develop on the head and extremities. Additionally, these lesions are more commonly brown, tan, or skin-colored and do not bleed with trauma as readily as the lesions seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Cherry angiomas are benign, vascular proliferations that commonly develop in adult patients. The diagnosis is typically made based on the clinical appearance of multiple, bright red, dome-shaped papules on the trunk and upper extremities that bleed with trauma and usually blanch with pressure. These lesions manifest more frequently with age and do not regress. Histologically, they are characterized by dilated interconnecting capillaries within the papillary dermis. No treatment is necessary unless lesions become bothersome (e.g., if they catch on clothing, bleed frequently, or are cosmetically unappealing). Options for removal include electrodessication, laser ablation, and surgical excision.

Key learning point: Cherry angiomas are common, benign vascular papules in adults that appear as bright red, dome-shaped lesions on the trunk and bleed easily with trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Bartonella henselae infections cause bacillary angiomatosis, which manifests with vascular proliferations that bleed with trauma, like the lesions seen in this patient. Although the lesions of bacillary angiomatosis can manifest with a papular appearance, they also commonly manifest as nodular, pedunculated, or verrucous lesions. In addition, this condition usually develops in patients infected with HIV, of which there is no indication here.
questions.hint: This middle-aged man presents with bright red papules that bleed with traumatic rupture, which suggests that the lesions are highly vascular.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to your clinic by his mother because of a dark red mass on his left thumb. The lesion developed after his cat scratched his left thumb and has rapidly increased in size over the past 2 months. It is not painful, but bled profusely once when he accidentally bumped his hand on a desk. He does not take any medications. Vital signs are normal. Examination of the left upper extremity reveals a solitary 2-cm lesion on the interphalangeal joint of the thumb; a photograph of the lesion is provided. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A keloid scar typically develops at the site of a wound 3–12 months after the injury, similar to what is seen in this patient, who was scratched by a cat 6 months ago. However, a keloid scar consists of brownish-red scar tissue with a claw-like appearance that grows beyond the boundaries of the injury, unlike what is seen here. Furthermore, in contrast to this patient's presentation, a keloid scar is usually painful, pruritic, and does not bleed following minor trauma.

B) INCORRECT:

A cherry hemangioma can manifest as a painless, red lesion that may bleed profusely after trauma. However, cherry hemangiomas are usually seen in adults older than 30 years of age and rarely occur on the hands. Moreover, multiple, smaller (0.1–0.4 cm) lesions rather than a single nodule are typically seen.

C) INCORRECT:

A glomus tumor can manifest as a red-purple nodule on the fingers. However, glomus tumors are typically located on the nail bed or the palm and are associated with severe paroxysmal pain, tenderness, and cold sensitivity. Furthermore, a glomus tumor does not usually bleed following minor trauma or develop at the site of an injury.

D) CORRECT:

Pyogenic granuloma (PG) is a benign, vascular tumor characterized by rapid growth and a tendency to bleed profusely after minor trauma. PG typically manifests as a painless, red papule or nodule and often develops at sites of skin injury on the face or hands, as seen here. The exact cause is unknown. Young men and pregnant women are commonly affected. Diagnosis is based on clinical findings but a histopathological confirmation can help to rule out malignant tumors. Surgical excision is the preferred method of treatment because it reduces the recurrence rate. Other methods of treatment include laser therapy, cryotherapy, intralesional steroid injections, and topical therapies (e.g., beta-blockers).

Key learning point: Pyogenic granuloma is a benign, rapidly growing vascular lesion that often develops after skin injury and bleeds easily with minor trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Kaposi sarcoma can manifest with a painless, red-brown nodule. However, multiple lesions on the lower legs, chest, and/or mucous membranes are typically seen. Moreover, Kaposi sarcoma is typically seen in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., individuals with HIV, organ transplant recipients) and does not usually lead to profuse bleeding following minor trauma.
questions.hint: This condition typically develops following skin trauma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with no significant medical history comes to your clinic because he has noticed a lump on his right upper arm for the past 2 years. The lump is not painful and has grown only slightly during this time. He mentions that his father had similar lesions. On examination, you palpate a 3.5-cm, soft, mobile subcutaneous nodule on the right upper arm (figure). Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leukemia cutis is a rare complication of leukemia that involves infiltration of the skin by leukemic cells. The lesions are typically smooth, firm plaques or nodules that are pink or violaceous in color. They can be distinguished from lipomas by their firmness and superficial skin changes, but definitive diagnosis requires a skin biopsy.

B) INCORRECT:

Epidermal inclusion cysts are derived from the upper portion of hair follicles (infundibulum) and are filled with keratin and lipid. They are mobile, like lipomas, but tend to be firmer and less compressible. They also often have a central punctum on the overlying skin and may drain a cheese-like substance, which is the keratin debris. They can become painful and erythematous if inflamed, sometimes necessitating surgical removal.

C) INCORRECT:

Skin abscesses are localized inflammatory responses to infection. Unlike lipomas, which are asymptomatic, abscesses are tender, erythematous, warm, and fluctuant. They may also be associated with fevers and manifest more acutely than this patient’s lipoma has. The most commonly implicated pathogen is Staphylococcus aureus.

D) CORRECT:

Lipomas are benign tumors of mature fat cells and manifest as soft, mobile subcutaneous nodules without overlying skin changes. They can occur in any part of the body where fat is found and can range in size from a few millimeters to several centimeters. They are usually asymptomatic, but if they start to compress nerves or become very large, they can be painful. Lipomas may be hereditary, particularly in people who have several lipomas. Symptomatic lipomas can be surgically removed.

Key learning point: A lipoma, the most common soft-tissue tumor, appears as a soft, mobile subcutaneous mass.

E) INCORRECT:

Erythema nodosum is the most common form of panniculitis (inflammation of subcutaneous fat). It manifests as an ill-defined, erythematous nodule or plaque, usually over the legs, that can be tender. Unlike lipomas, the lesions of erythema nodosum are not mobile or well-defined. Erythema nodosum is often idiopathic but can be caused by streptococcal pharyngitis and more-systemic inflammatory conditions, such as tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, cancer, and inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a 3-week history of a growing nodule on his thumb that developed after sustaining a minor cut from a piece of metal. The lesion is shown. It is friable and bleeds easily with minimal palpation. He denies fever, lymphadenopathy, or similar lesions elsewhere. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Topical antibiotic ointment and dressing change

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This presentation is consistent with pyogenic granuloma, a benign vascular tumor that develops following trauma. Topical antibiotics are not effective for this condition since pyogenic granulomas are not infectious processes despite their misleading name, and require definitive removal rather than antimicrobial therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

This clinical presentation suggests pyogenic granuloma, a benign vascular tumor characterized by rapid growth and bleeding after minor trauma. Oral antibiotics would not address this condition, as pyogenic granulomas are not caused by bacterial infection but rather represent vascular proliferation following tissue injury.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This presentation is consistent with pyogenic granuloma, evidenced by rapid growth following trauma, friable appearance, and tendency to bleed easily. Emergency physicians should provide hemostasis for active bleeding and arrange referral for definitive excision by a qualified specialist.

D) INCORRECT:

This likely represents a pyogenic granuloma based on the rapid growth following trauma and characteristic friable, bleeding appearance. While biopsy could be considered for atypical presentations, this clinically typical lesion is better managed with referral for excision, which provides both diagnostic tissue and definitive treatment simultaneously.

E) INCORRECT:

This clinical presentation suggests pyogenic granuloma, a benign vascular tumor that proliferates rapidly and bleeds easily. Observation alone is inappropriate for actively bleeding lesions that continue to grow, as the tendency to bleed and proliferate makes referral for removal necessary to prevent ongoing complications.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with a 6-week history of several soft and mobile palpable masses on his right forearm, as shown. The patient reports no pain, and the masses have remained stable in size since he first noticed them. He has a history of similar lesions on his back that have been present for years without change. Which additional clinical feature would be most concerning for malignancy?

choices.text: Firmness and immobility of one mass
One mass increasing to 4 cm over the past month

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – The clinical features strongly suggest benign lipomas: multiple soft, mobile, superficial masses that are stable and painless, with a history of similar stable lesions. However, one mass becoming firm and fixed to the underlying tissue would be highly concerning, as this suggests involvement of deeper structures and potential invasion, which is a key feature distinguishing liposarcoma from benign lipoma.

B) INCORRECT:

The presentation is consistent with benign lipomas, given the soft, mobile, superficial nature and stability of the masses. Mild intermittent tenderness would not be highly concerning for malignancy, as many benign lipomas can develop mild discomfort, especially if subject to trauma or pressure.

C) INCORRECT:

This clinical presentation is typical of benign lipomas with their soft, mobile, superficial characteristics and stable course. A family history of lipomas would actually support this benign diagnosis, as familial multiple lipomatosis is a recognized benign condition that would be reassuring rather than concerning.

D) INCORRECT:

These masses have the classic features of benign lipomas: soft, mobile, superficial, and stable. Overlying skin discoloration alone would not be the most concerning feature, as skin changes can occur with benign masses due to pressure effects or superficial vascular changes without indicating malignant transformation.

E) INCORRECT:

The clinical features are consistent with benign lipomas, given their soft, mobile, superficial nature and stable course. While one mass increasing to 4 cm over the past month would be somewhat concerning and warrant monitoring, this growth pattern alone is less alarming than changes in consistency and mobility. Benign lipomas can occasionally show periods of more noticeable growth, and the 4 cm size remains below the 5 cm threshold that is highly suggestive of soft tissue sarcoma.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a 4-day history of worsening pain in a subcutaneous nodule on her posterior neck. She states the lesion has been present for approximately 2 years and was previously asymptomatic. Physical examination shows a 2.5-cm dome-shaped, firm, mobile mass with surrounding erythema and warmth. A small central dark spot is visible, and gentle pressure expresses thick, foul-smelling material. Her vital signs are normal and she appears well. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Incision and drainage with antibiotic therapy
Complete surgical excision with primary closure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While facial cysts should be referred to dermatology, this neck lesion with classic features of an infected epidermoid cyst requires immediate management in the emergency department. The diagnosis is clinical, and the acute infection must be addressed before any elective referral.

B) INCORRECT:

Intralesional steroids are used for ruptured or inflamed cysts to accelerate resolution, but this patient has signs of infection requiring drainage and antibiotics. Steroid injection alone would be inappropriate as it could worsen the infection.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation of a characteristic dome-shaped, mobile mass with a central punctum, malodorous discharge, and signs of infection (pain, erythema, warmth) is consistent with an infected epidermoid cyst. Infected cysts require incision and drainage with antibiotic therapy. Complete surgical excision should be deferred until after resolution of the acute infection to prevent recurrence and complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Observation with warm compresses is insufficient for an infected cyst. The presence of purulent discharge, erythema, and increasing pain indicates active infection requiring drainage and antibiotics.

E) INCORRECT:

Complete surgical excision during the acute inflammatory phase is not recommended. Surgical excision should be performed after the inflammation has resolved to prevent recurrence. Operating during active infection increases the risk for incomplete removal and complications.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents for evaluation of a slowly enlarging, non-painful lump on his upper back that has been present for 6 months. He denies any trauma or drainage from the site. On examination, there is a 2-cm, firm, dome-shaped, mobile subcutaneous nodule. The overlying skin appears unremarkable. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most characteristic of this lesion?

choices.text: A soft, lobulated, and doughy texture
Invagination of the lesion with direct pressure

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A key diagnostic feature of epidermoid cysts is the presence of a central punctum, which appears as a small, dark, comedone-like opening. This punctum represents the connection to the original hair follicle from which the cyst is derived. Epidermoid cysts are typically mobile, non-tender, and slowly enlarging. While often asymptomatic, they can become inflamed or rupture, leading to a sterile abscess-like reaction. Definitive treatment, if desired for cosmetic reasons or due to symptoms, involves complete surgical excision of the cyst and its wall to prevent recurrence.

B) INCORRECT:

This finding, known as the Fitzpatrick sign or "dimple sign," is characteristic of a dermatofibroma. A dermatofibroma is a firm dermal papule that tethers the epidermis, causing it to retract downward when pinched. The lesion in this patient is described as a mobile subcutaneous nodule, which is inconsistent with the typically fixed, intradermal nature of a dermatofibroma.

C) INCORRECT:

Transillumination is a technique used to determine if a mass is fluid-filled or solid. A mass that transilluminates, such as a ganglion cyst, will glow when a light is shone through it. The contents of an epidermoid cyst are thick, cheesy keratinaceous debris, which is semi-solid and does not allow light to pass through. Therefore, this lesion would not transilluminate.

D) INCORRECT:

A soft, doughy, or rubbery consistency is the classic description of a lipoma, which is a benign tumor of adipose tissue. While lipomas are also mobile and subcutaneous, the lesion in this patient is described as firm, making a lipoma less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

The ability to invaginate a soft cutaneous tumor through a defect in the underlying fascia is known as the "buttonhole sign." This finding is pathognomonic for a neurofibroma, particularly in the context of neurofibromatosis type 1. The lesion in this patient is described as firm, which is not typical for a neurofibroma that exhibits this sign.
questions.hint: The lesion described in this patient is most likely an epidermoid cyst.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents for evaluation of a skin lesion on his upper back. The nodule has been present for approximately three years and has slowly increased in size. It is generally painless but occasionally becomes tender. He denies any fever or systemic symptoms. On physical examination, there is a 2-cm, firm, mobile, dome-shaped subcutaneous nodule with a small, dark, centrally located pore on the surface. Gentle pressure on the lesion extrudes a small amount of thick, white, malodorous material. A photomicrograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A lipoma is a common, slow-growing, benign tumor of adipose tissue. While it presents as a mobile subcutaneous mass, it is characteristically soft, rubbery, and "doughy" to palpation, not firm. Additionally, a lipoma lacks a central punctum and does not contain material that can be expressed through the skin surface.

B) INCORRECT:

Nodular basal cell carcinoma can present as a firm, dome-shaped nodule. However, its classic appearance is a pearly papule with overlying telangiectasias, and it may eventually ulcerate and bleed. It does not have a central punctum from which keratinous material can be expressed. The three-year history of slow growth without malignant features makes this diagnosis less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

A dermatofibroma is a firm, benign dermal papule or nodule, most common on the lower extremities. It is a proliferation of fibroblasts and characteristically exhibits a positive "dimple sign" (central depression with lateral pressure), which is not described here. It does not have a central pore or extrude any material.

D) INCORRECT:

A pilar cyst (trichilemmal cyst) is also a firm, mobile, keratin-filled nodule. However, over 90% of pilar cysts occur on the scalp. A key differentiating feature is that pilar cysts typically lack the central punctum seen in this patient's lesion on his upper back. They arise from the outer root sheath of the hair follicle.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for an epidermoid cyst, a benign subcutaneous lesion. The key diagnostic features are the firm, mobile nodule with a central punctum (the dark pore), which represents a keratin-plugged follicular opening. The extrusion of thick, cheesy, malodorous material upon pressure is pathognomonic. This material consists of macerated keratin produced by the cyst's epithelial lining, which is derived from the infundibulum of a hair follicle. These cysts are typically slow-growing and asymptomatic but can become inflamed or rupture, leading to tenderness, as occasionally experienced by this patient. Common locations include the face, neck, and trunk.
